bibl.title: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, November 12, 1938

div1.p: Andrus writes about an additional claimant to the yellow fever Roll of Honor: John Morris. He thinks it is unlikely that Moran will assist with the Lambert/Ames appeal.

div1.head: Letter from John H. Andrus to Gustaf E. Lambert, November 12, 1938
div1.opener:
J.H. Andrus
805 Cooper St.
Camden, N. J.
11-12-38
FROM GUST LAMBERT
Dear Friend Lambert:
div1.p:
Had a letter from our Friend Schwiegerna few days ago and
he tells me you have been in rather poor health. Am
very sorry. Hope you will be restored to your normal
self before this reaches you.

In your last letter you said you had heard from John S.
Morris. He called to see me several times this summer
and would like help to get on the honor roll. If he
ever had any connection whatever with the work of Major
Reed's yellow fever commission I have absolutely no know-
ledge of it.

I am willing to do everything within my limited power to
help a comrade who has not been fairly treated BUT I am
not disposed to give a boost to everyone who happened to
be in Cuba while these experiments were going on - espec-
ially when I would have to commit perjury to do so.

You will recall that I wrote to John J. Moran with the
idea of sounding him out relative help for Dr. Ames and
yourself. I am not going to tell you what he said in
detail but assure you that any statement you are likely
to get from him will be of no value to either case.

He quotes from letters from Major Keen to him which indi-
cate that there were many who tried to climb aboard the
annuity bandwagon. This probably explains why the Sur-
geon General's office is so hard boiled.

What did you think of the bill to give Kissinger the stat-
us of a retired major? I do not think that there is any
possibility of enactment.

I believe you are mistaken about the salability of anything
I cold write about the experiments. The public seems to
want romance and - as you are well aware - there was little
love and no kisses in this work.

Mrs. Andrus joins me in sending kindest regards and best
wishes to Mrs. Lambert and yourself.
